required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mini Stem DEXA (Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry)
clinical_study.official_title: Bone Density by Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) Following Total Hip Arthroplasty With the "Short Mini Stem"

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to evaluate the bone ingrowth after implantation of the study device. This study will also document any device-related surgical complications or adverse radiographic observations. Improvement in pain, function, and health economic data will be compared with improvements documented with other joint systems.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of the current investigation is to assess the bone ingrowth after implantation with a modular, short hip stem using Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA). The intended use of this product is for patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease who require a primary total hip replacement.

primary_outcome.measure: DEXA Analysis of BMD at Preoperative Visit
primary_outcome.description: DEXA=Dual Energy X-Ray Absorptiometry; BMD=Bone Mineral Density; The proximal femur was divided into 7 regions relative to the length of the stem. Lateral portions = region 1, region 2 and region 3; The entire bone mass immediately distal to the stem tip = region 4; Medial portions = region 5, region 6, and region 7. Mean BMD was calculated for each femoral region. BMD values were adjusted peri-prosthetically to account for stem area.

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline Harris Hip Score (HHS) at Preoperative Visit
secondary_outcome.description: The HHS is a physician tool to measure how a subject is doing following hip replacement surgery using the following scale: Total Scale Ranges: Excellent: 90 - 100 Good: 80 - 89 Fair: 70 - 79 Poor: 60 - 69 Very Poor: <60 Subscore Ranges: Pain: 0 - 44 Function: 0 - 47 Absence of Deformity: 0 - 4 Range of Motion: 0 - 5 The score ranges from 0 to 100, where, the higher the score, the better the subject outcome. Lower scores indicate a higher level of dysfunction due to hip problems.

Lower scores indicate a higher level of dysfunction due to hip problems.

secondary_outcome.measure: Hip Injury Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS) at Preoperative Visit
secondary_outcome.description: The HOOS is a questionnaire that the subject completes focusing on hip pain, stiffness, and function relating to osteoarthritis of the hip. The HOOS consists of 40 items assessing 5 subscales. The 5 separate patient-relevant dimensions are Symptoms and Stiffness, Pain, Function in Daily Living, Function in Sport and Recreation, and Hip-Related Quality of Life (QoL). Pain includes 10 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points Symptoms includes 5 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points Function in Daily Living includes 17 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points Function in Sport and Recreation and Hip-Related QoL each include 4 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points. Each sub-score was transformed in a worst to best scale (0-100), where 100 indicates no symptoms and 0 indicates extreme symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Radiographic Assessment at Preoperative Visit (Yes/No Components)
secondary_outcome.description: Radiographs were obtained from the anteroposterior (AP) view as well as the lateral view. The span of the bone-prosthesis interface for each component was broken down into zone systems. The scoring system was based on the measurement of radiolucent lines (in millimeters) in each zone. The checklist reviewed radiolucencies, migration, osteolysis, and stress shielding. The Brooker Classification was defined as: Class 0 - absence of radiographic heterotopic ossification Class 1 - islands of bone within soft tissues Class 2 - bone spurs originating from pelvis or proximal end of femur with at least 1 cm between opposing bone surfaces Class 3 - bone spurs originating from pelvis or proximal end of femur reduced to <1 cm Class 4 - apparent bone ankyloses of the hip

secondary_outcome.measure: Radiographic Assessment at 3 Month Visit (Yes/No Components)
secondary_outcome.description: Radiographs were obtained from the anteroposterior (AP) view as well as the lateral view. The checklist reviewed radiolucencies, migration, osteolysis, and stress shielding. study_pop.textblock: The purpose of this investigation is to assess the bone growth after implantation with a modular, short hip stem using Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA). The intended use of this product is for patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease who require a total hip replacement.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient has hip disease that requires a total hip arthroplasty.
- Patient is willing to consent to participate in the study.
- Patient plans to be available for the study duration.
- Patient is in stable health and is free of or treated and stabilized for cardiac, pulmonary, hematological, or other conditions that would pose excessive operative risk.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient known to have insufficient bone stock.
- Patient has had major non-arthroscopic surgery to the study hip.
- Patient has physical, emotional or neurological conditions that would compromise the patient's compliance with postoperative rehabilitation and follow-up.
- Patient has a known sensitivity to materials in the device.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This study was conducted by 1 investigator in 1 country from 14 Sep 2009 to 18 Apr 2016.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: A total of 22 subjects were screened, with 20 subjects enrolled and had surgery/MIS implanted.

group.title: MIS (Mini Stem) Stem
group.description: Patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease (DJD) who required a primary total hip replacement (THR) and had the MIS femoral stem/modular neck implanted. There was no assignment of study treatment: all subjects had implantation of the MIS femoral stem/modular neck during total hip arthroplasty (THA).

group.title: MIS Stem
group.description: Patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease (DJD) who required a primary total hip replacement (THR) and had the MIS femoral stem/modular neck implanted. All subjects had implantation of the MIS femoral stem/modular neck during THA. DEXA was used to assess the bone ingrowth and detect significant alterations in skeletal structure that may not be visible during routine clinical assessment.

Sex: Female, Male
Race/Ethnicity, Customized

Lateral portions = region 1, region 2 and region 3; The entire bone mass immediately distal to the stem tip = region 4; Medial portions = region 5, region 6, and region 7. Mean BMD was calculated for each femoral region. BMD values were adjusted peri-prosthetically to account for stem area.

outcome.title: Baseline Harris Hip Score (HHS) at Preoperative Visit
outcome.description: The HHS is a physician tool to measure how a subject is doing following hip replacement surgery using the following scale: Total Scale Ranges: Excellent: 90 - 100 Good: 80 - 89 Fair: 70 - 79 Poor: 60 - 69 Very Poor: <60 Subscore Ranges: Pain: 0 - 44 Function: 0 - 47 Absence of Deformity: 0 - 4 Range of Motion: 0 - 5 The score ranges from 0 to 100, where, the higher the score, the better the subject outcome. Lower scores indicate a higher level of dysfunction due to hip problems.

outcome.title: Harris Hip Score (HHS) at 2 Year Visit
outcome.description: The HHS is a physician tool to measure how a subject is doing following hip replacement surgery using the following scale: Total Scale Ranges: Excellent: 90 - 100 Good: 80 - 89 Fair: 70 - 79 Poor: 60 - 69 Very Poor: <60 Subscore Ranges: Pain: 0 - 44 Function: 0 - 47 Absence of Deformity: 0 - 4 Range of Motion: 0 - 5 The score ranges from 0 to 100, where, the higher the score, the better the subject outcome. Lower scores indicate a higher level of dysfunction due to hip problems.
outcome.population: Number of participants returning for this time point visit assessment.

group.title: MIS Stem
group.description: Patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease (DJD) who required a primary total hip replacement (THR) and had the MIS femoral stem/modular neck implanted.

measure.title: Harris Hip Score (HHS) at 5 Year Visit
measure.description: The HHS is a physician tool to measure how a subject is doing following hip replacement surgery using the following scale: Total Scale Ranges: Excellent: 90 - 100 Good: 80 - 89 Fair: 70 - 79 Poor: 60 - 69 Very Poor: <60 Subscore Ranges: Pain: 0 - 44 Function: 0 - 47 Absence of Deformity: 0 - 4 Range of Motion: 0 - 5 The score ranges from 0 to 100, where, the higher the score, the better the subject outcome. Lower scores indicate a higher level of dysfunction due to hip problems.
measure.population: Number of participants returning for this time point visit assessment.

outcome.title: Hip Injury Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS) at Preoperative Visit
outcome.description: The HOOS is a questionnaire that the subject completes focusing on hip pain, stiffness, and function relating to osteoarthritis of the hip. The HOOS consists of 40 items assessing 5 subscales. The 5 separate patient-relevant dimensions are Symptoms and Stiffness, Pain, Function in Daily Living, Function in Sport and Recreation, and Hip-Related Quality of Life (QoL). Pain includes 10 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points Symptoms includes 5 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points Function in Daily Living includes 17 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points Function in Sport and Recreation and Hip-Related QoL each include 4 items with a total score of 0 - 100 points. Each sub-score was transformed in a worst to best scale (0-100), where 100 indicates no symptoms and 0 indicates extreme symptoms.

group.title: MIS Stem
group.description: Patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease (DJD) who required a primary total hip replacement (THR) and had the MIS femoral stem/modular neck implanted.

outcome.title: Radiographic Assessment at Preoperative Visit (Yes/No Components)
outcome.description: Radiographs were obtained from the anteroposterior (AP) view as well as the lateral view. The span of the bone-prosthesis interface for each component was broken down into zone systems. The scoring system was based on the measurement of radiolucent lines (in millimeters) in each zone. The checklist reviewed radiolucencies, migration, osteolysis, and stress shielding. The Brooker Classification was defined as: Class 0 - absence of radiographic heterotopic ossification Class 1 - islands of bone within soft tissues Class 2 - bone spurs originating from pelvis or proximal end of femur with at least 1 cm between opposing bone surfaces Class 3 - bone spurs originating from pelvis or proximal end of femur reduced to <1 cm Class 4 - apparent bone ankyloses of the hip

group.title: MIS Stem
group.description: Patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease (DJD) who required a primary total hip replacement (THR) and had the MIS femoral stem/modular neck implanted. There was no assignment of study treatment: all subjects had implantation of the MIS femoral stem/modular neck during THA.

reported_events.time_frame: The time frame for collection of AEs is from the signing of the Informed Consent through Study Exit, an average of 5 years.
reported_events.desc: Device-related adverse events are defined as any of the following: any device implant component failure including any of the following exact or similar descriptive nomenclature: a) revision, fracture, crack, chip, flake, split, splinter, shatter, break, or wear-through; b) device wear particle induced osteolysis, inflammation, etc. (wear debris may be metal and/or UHMWPE in composition); and c) any device component experiencing dislocation, subluxation, subsidence, migration, or loosening.

group.title: MIS Stem
group.description: Patients with non-inflammatory and inflammatory degenerative joint disease (DJD) who required a primary total hip replacement (THR) and had the MIS femoral stem/modular neck implanted. There was no assignment of study treatment: all subjects had implantation of the MIS femoral stem/modular neck during THA.

event.sub_title: Cut hand - hospital admission for intervenous (IV) antibiotics
Unicompartmental knee replacement secondary to OA
Subsidence of femoral prosthesis; revision in THR
Mild sclerosis over weight-bearing aspect of acetabulum on x-ray
Condensation around tip of stem on x-ray femur

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: There was a decreased compliance rate at the 3 year follow-up and a 50% termination rate by the 5 year follow-up resulting in a much smaller sample sizes for data collection.
